author: bobcat6146
content: Once key file unified, how is it going to be used? Still provide password in validator command line / store private key in a file - a big no no ? Or sign the key file with private key when key file is deployed to a device? Sign key file against CPU serial number, like Microsoft does in Windows activation, can prevent hacker steal key files and put them on another computer, lunch slashing attack.

author: ralexstokes
content: <@!387720149345763329> there will likely be a bunch of different strategies around protecting private keys -- using EIP 2335 standard will be helpful if we wish to write private keys to disk but you could imagine fancier setups w/ secure hardware where the exact format is less importnat

author: ralexstokes
content: one thing that immediately comes to mind is that if you are e.g. controlling a bunch of validators in a testnet (or really mainnet) you don't want to have to sit and enter all of the passwords for each private key individually

author: bobcat6146
content: <@!539495253418180618> in prysm validator, people use one password for all their key files. that is very convenient and OK for single person staking. for individual, two to three different passwords are max, otherwise crazy.

author: ralexstokes
content: agreed

author: ralexstokes
content: i guess nothing is stopping you from using a few passwords across many key files

author: bobcat6146
content: I can use one password for a batch, and deploy that batch into one machine, hopefully they can be activated on that machine and restricted to be used only on that machine due to CPU id bound. then i can use 2nd password, generate 2nd batch of key files, do mass deposit for 2nd batch, deploy the batch to another machine on 2nd site.

author: ralexstokes
content: just depends on your threat model ðŸ™‚

author: bobcat6146
content: right

author: bobcat6146
content: based on the operational procedures described above, it'd be nice to have this feature: when generating key files, able to specify a file name prefix such as "batch1_", "batch2", albeit one can rename them manually later.

author: bobcat6146
content: another feature is to have multiple --datadir for key files location. that way one can separate batch generated key files into different folders, such as batch1-keyfiles-folder, batch2-keyfiles-folder, instead of put all files in one folder and rely solely on file name prefix.

author: bobcat6146
content: besides, in 2 sites fail over operation, during fail over switch, let say from site 1 to site 2, in a machine of site 2, one can create a folder named site1-KeyFiles-Folder,  deploy the site 1 key files into that folder, then add --datadir=site1-KeyFiles-Folder to validator command line, which should already have --datadir=site2-keyFiles-Folder.
